channel.title: Art - Digg
channel.description: Art on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: Is Isolation Overrepresented In Street And Documentary Photography?
item.description: Isolating individuals in photographs can make for an interesting image, but an entire portfolio of these images contains a statement, whether intentional or otherwise.

item.title: Art Recreation Is The Only Good Instagram Challenge
item.description: Around the world, people are posing as famous portraits with toilet paper, bedsheets, drawn-on unibrows, and did we mention toilet paper?

item.title: Colorful Maps Of A World In Coronavirus Lockdown
item.description: Tight floor plans, "sanity" walks and the people you miss seeing: they turned up in your homemade maps of life during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Massive Wild Animals Wander Russian Streets In These Surreal Composites By Vadim Solovyov
item.description: Seeing a raccoon washing its paws in the rivers of Saint Petersburg or an octopus tumbling out of a city bus would be a startling sight for most city dwellers.

item.title: Every Day Since 1964, This Outsider Artist Made A Collage Of Found Objects
item.description: New Yorkers have a special relationship with trash, which is as much a fixture of the cityscape as the Manhattan skyline. Not to wax romantic about littering, but some of that, shall we say, "street ephemera" — the lost tickets, photos, business cards — can give us the most honest, intimate window into the city's stories.

item.title: Robot's AI-Enabled Room Painting Starts Off Weird And Then Quickly Escalates Into Delightful Chaos
item.description: Well, we wanted to paint the room a soft beige, but we guess we'll settle for chaotic neutral.

item.title: A Story In One Sentence
item.description: For the Spring issue, we asked the six fiction writers to select a single sentence that marked the moment they first knew what story they were writing.

item.title: Thieves Stole A Vincent Van Gogh Painting Worth Millions Last Week. This Is What Happens Next
item.description: What do the criminals do with The "Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring," and how could they get caught?

item.title: This Artist's Reimagining Of Disney Cartoons As Gory Horror Movies Is Ruining Our Childhoods
item.description: This is genius. This is horrifying.

item.title: How Can Broadway Recover From This Pandemic?
item.description: Even in the best of times, theater is the most fragile of the popular arts. Theater requires us sitting in the seats in order to be complete. It's an unequal love affair: we want theater but theater needs us. And in this pandemic, it is simply gone.
item.kicker: MURDER ON THE GREAT WHITE WAY

item.title: Inside The 'Circus Capital Of The World'
item.description: The big top came to Peru, Indiana in the late 19th century. It never left.

item.title: Artist Makes Sound Colorful And 'Visible' With Stunning Sand Art
item.description: Sound and color are married together in this perfect performance by artist Kenichi Kanazawa.
item.kicker: PAINT WITH THE COLORS OF THE WIND

item.title: The Photographer Couple Who Turned Industrial Architecture Into Fine Art
item.description: Together, Hilla and Bernd Becher documented the disappearing markers of industry across Europe and North America, including factory buildings, gas tanks and silos.

item.title: The World's Great Photographers, Many Stuck Inside, Have Snapped
item.description: Stephen Shore, Catherine Opie, Todd Hido and others have turned to Instagram to cure "corona claustrophobia" or show how life has changed. They talk about their quarantine pics.

item.title: Dav Pilkey Is Hosting Virtual Readings And Drawing Lessons
item.description: Dav Pilkey — author and illustrator of the "Captain Underpants" and "Dog Man" book series — is also stuck at home. So he's teaming up with the Library of Congress to read to our kids and help them learn to draw some of his most beloved characters.

item.title: Kanye West's High School Artwork Got Appraised On 'Antiques Roadshow' And Its Estimated Value Was Fascinating
item.description: In a recent episode of PBS's "Antiques Roadshow," Kanye West's cousin's husband brought in a trove of works the rapper made as a teen. The appraiser gave a very interesting analysis of the art.

item.title: A Peek At Utopian Space Dreams Behind The Iron Curtain
item.description: A new collection of Soviet space design is more relevant than ever.
item.kicker: 'WITHOUT YOUR PAST, YOU CANNOT MOVE ON'

item.title: As Long As You're Stuck In Your Apartment, Give Yourself A Story To Live
item.description: Artist Peter McGough has always insisted on living as if he's in another era. He shares his West Village railroad apartment with mementos and Queenie. Most days during quarantine, he wears one of his many silk bathrobes.

item.title: An Art Exhibit You Can Visit Without Leaving Your Couch
item.description: The creators of the Whitney Museum's New York Apartment explain how they combined thousands of listings into a website for one massive, $43.9 billion dwelling.

item.title: How To Take And Send Nudes
item.description: There's never been a better time to master the fine art of the naked selfie.

item.title: A Visual History Of Chinese Propaganda
item.description: Striking posters — taken from the 1920s to the present day — chart the country's emergence as an economic powerhouse.

item.title: Explore The World Of Photorealism From Around The World
item.description: From the '60s to modern day, check out a Photorealism art archive curated by Google.

item.title: An Amusing Comic That Captures Life From The Perspective Of A Virus
item.description: During these trying times, this comic from xkcd creator Randall Munroe might give you a good chuckle.

item.title: Things That Used To Be Annoying But Are Now A Comfort
item.description: The neighbors' trumpet never sounded so good.

item.title: Van Gogh Painting Stolen Amid Coronavirus Shutdown, Museum Director 'Incredibly Pissed'
item.description: On Monday, a Dutch museum announced that a painting by Vincent Van Gogh was missing after thieves broke into the building in an early-morning raid. Lentetuin, painted by Van Gogh in the spring of 1884, was on loan to the Singer Laren museum, which closed its doors earlier this month due to the risks of COVID-19.

item.title: 50 Works That Changed Our Critics' Lives
item.description: Our reviewers select standout moments in their field which still shape their love of the arts.

item.title: The Auction Game: Can You Guess How Much Different Artworks Sold For?
item.description: Neal Agarwal's "Auction Game" is like "The Price Is Right," but way, way harder.

item.title: The Colorful Photographs Of Everyday Life That Shocked The Art World And Changed Photography Forever
item.description: Self-taught photographer William Eggleston's vivid images of mundane scenes arrived at MoMA at a time when the only photographs considered to be art were in black and white.

item.title: The Charmed Second Life Of Australia's Cursed 'Disco Dong'
item.description: The sculpture was loathed as a public-art installation. Now its 4,000 aluminum birds are treasured in private collections.

item.title: 'I Was Always Astounded By The Level Of Constant Invention': On Terrence McNally
item.description: McNally's much-awarded work spans the last five decades of American drama, but for some of us, it also spans our lives in the theater.

item.title: Actors Are Reading Sonnets To Us Online To Soothe Our Isolation Anxieties
item.description: This week, actor Michael Gaston started #readasonnet, challenging his friends and colleagues directly to share sonnets with the world.

item.title: How Artist Edward Hopper Became The Poster Boy Of Quarantine Culture
item.description: The 20th-century American artist - known for his scenes of derelict urban life and social alienation - is going viral

item.title: The African-American Art Shaping The 21st Century
item.description: Kerry Washington on Beyonc√©, Ta-Nehisi Coates on Kendrick Lamar, Oprah Winfrey on Toni Morrison, Issa Rae on "Scandal," and 31 other prominent black artists on the work that inspires them most.

item.title: I Turned Pixel-Perfect Cities Into Psychedelic Hellscapes Using Machine Learning
item.description: Look, I may have accidentally summoned some demons from the pixel art underworld. I don't know what is happening to these little creatures, but it sure doesn't look good.

item.title: How To Support Arts Organizations While Practicing Social Distancing
item.description: Temporary closures are forcing businesses to look to community support. Here's how you can hel risk-free.

item.title: You Can Teach A Computer To Preserve Or Modify An Artistic Style Using Neural Networks
item.description: Using GANILLA (Generative Adversarial Networks for Image to Illustration Translation) computers are able to mimic, modify and create art based on the source you give it.

item.title: How Soviet Science Magazines Fantasized About Life In Outer Space
item.description: The Iron Curtain went to infinity and beyond.

item.title: My Friend, The International Art Con Man
item.description: For a few years, Inigo Philbrick and I were inseparable. And then it turned out he was running a con.

item.title: All Broadway Shows Will Close For A Month Due To Coronavirus
item.description: The Metropolitan Opera, Carnegie Hall and the New York Philharmonic also announced closures.

item.title: How This Man Seemingly Defies Gravity To Balance Dozens Of Rocks On Top Of Each Other
item.description: Michael Grab has an extraordinary talent for balancing rocks without glue or metal rods.

item.title: Shakespeare And The Culture Wars: On The Movement For Color-Blind Casting
item.description: "Actors speaking Shakespeare's words have begun to resemble the nation."

item.title: The Art Of The Post: The Mystery Of Walter Hunt Everett
item.description: What happens when a brilliant young artist suddenly disappears?

item.title: Original Salvador Dali Artwork Discovered At North Carolina Thrift Store
item.description: A valuable piece of art was almost lost, until someone with a sharp eye found it at a thrift store on the Outer Banks late last year.

item.title: Why Medieval Cats Look Like... That
item.description: "Those cat paintings always look like someone told the painter what a cat was, but didn't bother to explain that they aren't tiny humans who are haunting the homes of noblemen."
item.kicker: PUT THAT CAT BACK IN THE BAG

item.title: What Andy Warhol Was Really Like, By The People Who Knew Him Best
item.description: From never taking his wig off to being far from asexual, the artist's nephews, friends, and colleagues share their memories of "the real Andy."

item.title: I Can't Look Away From These Delirious Paintings Of Anthropomorphized Books
item.description: British artist Jonathan Wolstenholme's watercolors are so weird and so wonderful.

item.title: A Collection Of 'Fossils' Of Popular Cartoon Characters
item.description: A series imagining realistic skulls based on cartoon characters.

item.title: National Park Illustrations, Based On Their Worst One-Star Reviews
item.description: I'm an illustrator and I have always had a personal goal to draw all 62 US National Parks, but I wanted to find a unique twist for the project.

item.title: From Death Cab To The Grateful Dead, An Artist Reimagines The Classic Rock Poster
item.description: Despite the distinct musical tastes of these band's audiences, one artist had been selected to produce limited-edition screenprints for all of them, a 22-year-old Baltimorean named Luke Martin.

item.title: The Cure For Creative Envy
item.description: Writers, artists and performers are highly susceptible to envy. Here's how to conquer it, focus on your own work and put your creativity into perspective.
